Make the compass go through one complete rotation
What happens to the compass when it moves around the electromagnet?
A compass is a free magnet. Its North is attracted to the Electro Magnet's South pole
Understand the magnetic field around the electromagnet
Touch the screen in many places around the electromagnet to see the field.
The field due to an Electromagnet is very similar to that due to a bar magnet
It has two poles - North and South where the field is strongest
Move the electromagnet. See how the field changes.
When the electromagnet moves, its magnetic field moves along with it.
Change the radius of the electromagnet coil. See how the field changes.
The magnetic strength is proportional to the loop area of the electromagnet
When radius increases, the magnetic strength increases and vice versa
Change the current direction. See how the field changes.
The magnetic field direction is given by the thumb in the Right Hand Grip rule where you curl right hand into a fist with fingers curling in direction of current.
Change the max current. See how the field changes.
As the current increases, the strength of the magnetic field increases.
Change the current type to AC. See how the field changes
When the current alternates, the electromagnet's magnetic field also alternates.
Change the number of coil loops on the Electromagnet. See how the magnetic field changes
When the number of coil loops on the Electromagnet increases, the strength of the magnetic field increases
Understand the magnetic field around the electromagnet
Touch one of the two ? where the magnetic field is stronger
The field is stronger closer to the poles of the magnet
The field is stronger if the current strength is larger
The field is stronger closer to the poles of the magnet.
The field also becomes stronger if the current strength is larger
Touch the ? and Drag in the direction of the magnetic field
The direction of the field arrow at a point is away from the North Pole and towards the South Pole of the magnet.
The nearer pole affects it more.
The right hand grip rule gives the direction of the magnetic field with respect to current direction
In an ElectroMagnet, the magnetic field is
strongest close to the South Pole Only
strongest close to the North Pole Only
strongest exactly midway between North pole and South Pole
Uniform along the length of the magnet
strongest near North and South Poles
An ElectroMagnet has the following poles
When the direction of current in an ElectroMagnet is reversed
its magnetic field direction stays the same
With alternating current in an ElectroMagnet
there will be a constant magnetic field perpendicular to the ElectroMagnet
there will be an alternating magnetic field

What happens to the magnetic field intensity if the current carrying wire has three times as many loops, and the same amount of current?
Magnetic field intensity increases in direction proportion to the number of loops of wire
Four solenoids have the same number of coil loops. Which one would produce the strongest magnetic field?
the solenoid with 1 A of current
the solenoid with 10 A of current
the solenoid with 100 A of current
the solenoid with 0.1 A of current
Magnetic field intensity increases in direction proportion to the current
Each of the following solenoids are similar and carry the same electric current. Which one would produce the strongest magnetic field?
Magnetic field intensity increases in direction proportion to the number of loops of wire
A magnetic field that is uniform can be found
The central inner region of a solenoid has a uniform magnetic field
A compass placed at the center of an electromagnet carrying alternating current
will point to North pole of earth
will point in a direction parallel to the axis of the electromagnet coils
The magnetic field direction changes with the current direction
A solenoid is suspended so it can rotate freely from 2 wires. When current flows through the solenoid,
it will swing to align in North South direction
it will swing to align in East West direction
The solenoid becomes magnetic and swings to align with the Earth's magnetic field
Each of the following solenoids are similar except for coil radius and carry the same electric current. Which one would produce the strongest magnetic field?
solenoid with a coil radius of 5
solenoid with a coil radius of 10
solenoid with a coil radius of 1
all will produce a magnetic field of the same strength
Magnetic field intensity increases in direction proportion to the number of loops of wire
